metadata.title: Street Use Permits in San Francisco
metadata.authority: SF Department of Public Works (DPW) Bureau of Street-Use and Mapping (BSM), SFMTA
notes: Street use permits are required whenever work or staging impacts the public right-of-way
DPW/BSM handles most street use permits; SFMTA handles curb zones and transit impacts
Street use permits are in addition to any building permits — they are separate applications
Failure to obtain street use permits can result in stop-work orders on adjacent building work
Bonds or insurance are typically required for excavation permits

dpw_bsm.name: DPW Bureau of Street-Use and Mapping (BSM)
dpw_bsm.contact: BSM Counter, 49 South Van Ness Ave

sfmta.name: San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency
handles: Construction zone permits impacting bus stops or Muni
sfmta.notes: SFMTA coordinates with DPW for permits impacting both parking and public works

permit_types.name: Excavation Permit
permit_types.description: Required for any excavation in the public right-of-way — trenching for utilities, sewer laterals, underground vaults
when_needed: Sewer lateral replacement requiring street or sidewalk cut
Water service connection from main to building
Utility installation or upgrade
Underground vault or cistern installation in sidewalk
permit_types.typical_fee: $500-$5,000 depending on trench length and location
requirements: Underground Service Alert (USA/811) notification required 2 business days before excavation
Performance bond or cash deposit required
Pavement restoration plan
Traffic control plan if street closure involved
Backfill compaction report after completion
permit_types.restoration: DPW requires pavement patching/restoration within 30 days of permit expiration; sidewalk must be restored to match existing

permit_types.name: Construction Occupancy (Staging) Permit
permit_types.description: Temporary occupancy of the sidewalk or parking lane for construction equipment, materials, or scaffolding
when_needed: Construction scaffolding over public sidewalk
Dumpster, storage container, or construction trailer in parking lane
Concrete pump truck or cement mixer staging
Temporary fencing enclosing sidewalk during demolition or construction
Crane pad in street or sidewalk
permit_types.typical_fee: $50-$300/day for sidewalk staging; meter hood fees separate
permit_types.duration: Project duration — typically 30-90 days with renewals
requirements: Pedestrian access maintained (5-ft minimum clear path or protected walkway)
Insurance certificate required ($1M liability minimum)
Temporary pedestrian walkway specs if sidewalk closed
Night lighting required if staging extends after sunset
Height restriction may apply under Muni overhead wires

permit_types.name: Sidewalk Repair Permit
permit_types.description: Required for any work in the sidewalk zone — replacement, extension, or new paving
when_needed: Damaged sidewalk replacement (owner responsibility under SF Public Works Code)
Sidewalk widening or narrowing
New sidewalk where none existed
Tree grate or planting area modification
permit_types.owner_liability: Property owners are responsible for sidewalk maintenance and repair — DPW can order repairs and bill owner
permit_types.standards: Sidewalks must meet DPW standard specifications: concrete mix, thickness, scoring pattern, ADA ramps at corners

permit_types.name: Curb Cut (Driveway) Permit
permit_types.description: Permission to create, modify, or remove a driveway opening in the curb
when_needed: New garage or parking area requiring curb cut
Widening existing driveway
Converting parking to other use (curb cut must be filled)
ADU with parking requirement
permit_types.jurisdiction: DPW/BSM (issues permit), Planning (reviews driveway locations on certain streets)
requirements: Minimum 18-ft setback from corner required
Not permitted on certain transit or bicycle priority streets
Planning review required on hills and certain neighborhoods

permit_types.name: Street Closure Permit
permit_types.description: Temporary closure of one or more traffic lanes or full street closure for construction or events
when_needed: Major demolition requiring lane closure
Tower crane erection over street
Large concrete pour requiring pump truck in street
Moving large equipment that cannot fit on sidewalk
requirements: Traffic Control Plan (TCP) prepared by licensed traffic engineer
SFMTA approval if Muni route affected
Police Department notification
Signage and barricade plan
Notice to adjacent businesses and residents
Minimum 48-hour notice to DPW

permit_types.name: Parklet Permit
permit_types.description: Conversion of on-street parking spaces to public outdoor seating or plaza (semi-permanent)
when_needed: Restaurant or cafe seeking outdoor seating in former parking spaces
Community organization creating neighborhood plaza
requirements: Design must meet DPW Parklet Guidelines
ADA accessibility compliance
Community outreach notification
Planning Department design review
SFMTA approval for parking removal

permit_types.name: Encroachment Permit
permit_types.description: Permanent or semi-permanent structure in the public right-of-way (stairs, stoops, planters, awnings)
when_needed: Steps or stoop that extends into sidewalk
Awning or canopy over sidewalk
Planter box in sidewalk zone
Bay window or building element overhanging sidewalk
Outdoor dining area on sidewalk (non-parklet)
requirements: Revocable encroachment agreement with DPW
Insurance required for larger structures
Must not obstruct fire hydrants, utility boxes, or ADA paths

when_both_required: Any project requiring a construction dumpster or materials in the parking lane or sidewalk
Projects requiring scaffolding over public right-of-way
Sewer lateral work that cuts the street or sidewalk
New construction or major remodel with delivery and staging needs
Excavation for foundation work near property line
relationship_to_building_permits.sequence: Building permits and street use permits are applied for separately but must coordinate on timeline. Building permit is typically filed first; street use permits are applied for as construction timing is known.
relationship_to_building_permits.note: A stop-work order on the street use permit (e.g., for unpermitted sidewalk occupation) can halt all associated construction work

duration_limits_and_renewals.standard_duration: Most street use permits are issued for 30-90 days
duration_limits_and_renewals.renewals: Available upon request with fee — most permits can be renewed if construction is ongoing
duration_limits_and_renewals.expiration_consequence: Failure to renew can result in fines; unrestore sidewalk/street triggers DPW emergency restoration at owner expense
duration_limits_and_renewals.long_term_construction: Projects over 6 months should plan for quarterly renewals of staging and excavation permits

common_mistakes.consequence: Risk of hitting underground utilities; criminal liability; DPW stop-work

common_mistakes.mistake: Placing dumpster without SFMTA meter hood permit
common_mistakes.consequence: Meter citation, dumpster removal by city at owner expense

common_mistakes.mistake: Not maintaining 5-ft pedestrian clearance when sidewalk is staging area
Failing to restore sidewalk after sewer lateral work
common_mistakes.consequence: DPW issues Notice of Violation; emergency restoration billed to property owner
